1A.  RISK FACTORS

The
Company’s reliance on a small number of customers for a large portion of its
revenues could harm its business and prospects. 
A number of contracts held by those customers may be terminated at the
customer’s discretion.

The
Company’s results of operations are affected by the overall economy and
governmental spending.

The
Company’s business is dependent upon governmental policies and appropriations.

The
Company’s lengthy sales cycle requires it to incur significant expenses with no
assurance that it will generate revenue or recover such expenses.

The
Company conducts its business worldwide, which exposes it to a number of
difficulties in coordinating its international activities and dealing with
multiple regulatory environments.

Changes
in governmental regulations may reduce demand for the Company’s products or
increase its expenses.

The
Company’s reliance on a limited number of suppliers for some key components for
its products could harm its business and prospects.

Fluctuations
in the Company’s operating results and unanticipated contract terminations may
cause its stock price to fluctuate.

The
Company could incur substantial costs as a result of product liability claims
and adverse publicity if its X-ray inspection systems fail to detect bombs,
explosives, weapons, contraband or other threats to personal safety.

The
Company’s insurance may be insufficient to protect it from product liability
claims.

The
Company may not be able to fund its research and development activities.

The
Company’s success depends on new product development.

The Company’s success
depends upon its ability to adapt to rapid changes in technology and customer
requirements.

The
Company may not be able to compete successfully.

The Company’s business could
be harmed if it is unable to protect its intellectual property.

The
Company’s business may be materially and adversely affected by infringement
claims initiated by the Company or its competitors.

The
Company’s success depends on its ability to attract and retain qualified
management professionals.

Existing
external financing may not be available in the future.

Future
sales of the Company’s common stock by existing stockholders could depress the
market price of the Company’s common stock.

The
volatility of the Company’s stock price could adversely affect an investment in
the Company’s common stock.

Provisions
in the Company’s articles of organization and the Company’s shareholder rights
plan may have the effect of discouraging advantageous offers for the Company’s
business or common stock, and limit the price that investors might be willing
to pay in the future for shares of the Company’s common stock.
